If you notice carefully, the url property uses the / route. You can change this inside the controller before rendering the view, as shown in the following example.
Finally, you must see the pagination links appear as shown in the following screenshot.

guides/database/pagination#serializing-t.title: Serializing to JSON
nodes: Serializing SimplePaginator instance to JSON is straight forward. Just call the .toJSON method and you will get JSON object as shown below:

guides/database/debugging-queries.title: Debugging Queries
nodes: The best way to debug queries is to listen for the db:query event and log every query to the console. To begin, lets create start/events.ts file using the following ace command.
Open the newly created file and paste the following code snippet inside it.
The start/events.ts file is registered inside .adonisrc.json and autoloaded during the application boot.
Next, you will have to enable the debug flag for your database connection inside the config/database.ts file.
That's all. Now, all the executed database queries will be pretty printed on the console as shown in the following screenshot.

guides/database/debugging-queries#how-it.title: How it works?
nodes: Lucid emits the
db:query
event for every SQL query executed by any part of your application.
You can manually handle the event or make use of the
Database.prettyPrint
method to log the query to the console with some colors and formatting.
The event is only emitted when
debug
flag is set to
true

guides/database/debugging-queries#debugg.title: Debugging in Production
nodes: The above setup is great for development as you can view every single pretty printed to the console for better readability. However, in production, it is recommended to use the Logger for logging queries in a serialized format and have minimum logging overhead.
Instead of using Database.prettyPrint you must use the Logger.debug method.
You can also conditionally decide the listener for the db:query event based upon the application environment.

guides/database/debugging-queries#select.title: Selectively Logging Queries
nodes: Logging every single query in production is not a great idea for following reasons.
You will degrade the performance of your application by increasing logging overhead.
Your logs will become too noisy.
If you are using a paid logging service, then you may end up paying more.

As a rule of thumb, you should always disable queries debugging in production by setting the debug = false inside the config/database.ts file, and then selectively debug individual queries that are critical for your application.
The query logging for an individual query can be enabled using the debug method.

guides/database/transactions.title: Transactions
nodes: Being an SQL ORM, Lucid has first class support for Transactions and save points. By the end of this guide, you will know:
How to create and manage transactions
How to create nested transactions (aka save points)
Using transactions with Lucid models
Persisting relationships inside a transaction

guides/database/transactions#working-wit.title: Working with Transactions
nodes: Creating a new transaction is as simple as executing the database.transaction method.
Once you have received the transaction instance, you can use it to execute queries.
Insert
Select
Finally, make sure to commit or rollback the transaction. For example:
Voila! You have just created and used a transaction.

guides/database/transactions#points-to-n.title: Points to Note
nodes: Just like the
Database
object, you can also use the
trx
object to create new instances of the query builder.
The
trx.commit
and
trx.rollback
methods are async, so do make sure to put
await
in front of them.
Lucid reserves a dedicated connection as soon as
Database.transaction()
method is called and releases the connection after commit or rollback actions.

guides/database/transactions#managed-tra.title: Managed Transactions
nodes: The above example expects you to manually commit or rollback transactions by wrapping your code inside a try/catch block. A managed transaction does this automatically for you. For example:
Passing a callback to the Database.transaction method starts a managed transaction.
The transaction auto commits after executing the callback.
If callback raises an exception, the transaction will be rolled back automatically and re-throws the exception.
You can also return a value from the callback and then access it at the top level scope. For example:

guides/database/transactions#passing-tra.title: Passing Transaction as a Reference
nodes: The transactions API is not only limited to creating a query builder instance from a transaction object. You can also pass it around to existing query builder instances or models.
Or pass it at a later stage using useTransaction method.

guides/database/transactions#save-points.title: Save points
nodes: Every time you create a nested transaction, Lucid behind the scenes creates a new savepoint. Since transactions need a dedicated connection, using savepoints reduces the number of required connections.

guides/database/transactions#using-trans.title: Using Transactions with Lucid Models
nodes: You can also make use of transactions when persisting or fetching rows using a Lucid model. For example:
As soon as the transaction is completed, the Model will release the trx reference.

guides/database/transactions#model-query.title: Model Query Builder
nodes: Just like the standard query builder, you can also pass the transaction to the model query builder.

guides/database/transactions#persisting-.title: Persisting Relationships Inside a Transaction
nodes: The most common use case for transactions is to persist relationships. Consider the following example of creating a new user and their profile by wrapping them inside a single transaction.
In the above query, the related('profile').create method will automatically use the transaction object assigned to the User model.

guides/database/migrations.title: Schema Migrations
nodes: So far you have learned about the ways to fetch or persist data using the database query builder. In this guide, we take a step further and explore schema migrations for creating/altering database tables.
By the end of this guide, you will know:
What is schema migrations and how it works
Using the Lucid Javascript API to create, alter or delete tables.
The Ace commands to run or rollback migrations.

guides/database/migrations#migrations-ov.title: Migrations Overview
nodes: Database schema migrations is one of the most confusing topics in software programming. Many times individuals don't even understand the need of using migrations vs manually creating database tables. So, let's take a step backward and explore the possible options for creating/modifying tables inside a database.
AdonisJS uses Knex.js behind the scene. Ensure to check out their documentation to see a full list of column types and modifier methods.

guides/database/migrations#using-a-gui-a.title: Using a GUI Application
nodes: The simplest way to create database tables is to make use of a GUI application like Sequel Pro, Table plus and so on. These applications are great during the development phase, however, they have some short-comings during the production workflow.
You need to expose your database server to the internet, so that the GUI application on your computer can connect to the production database.
You cannot tie the database changes to your deployment workflow. Every deployment impacting the database will require manual intervention.
Their is no history of your tables. You do not know, when and how a database modification was done.

guides/database/migrations#custom-sql-sc.title: Custom SQL Scripts
nodes: Another option is to create SQL scripts and run them during the deployment process. However, you will have to manually build a tracking system to ensure that you are not running the previously ran SQL scripts. For example:
You write a SQL script to create a new
users
table.
You run this script as part of the deployment workflow. However, you have to make sure that the next deployment must ignore the previously executed SQL script.

guides/database/migrations#using-schema-.title: Using Schema Migrations
nodes: Schema migrations address the above issues and offer a robust API for evolving and tracking database changes. There are many tools available for schema migrations ranging from framework agnostic tools like flywaydb to framework specific tooling offered by Rails, Laravel and so on.
Similarly, AdonisJS also has its own migrations system. You can create/modify database by just writing Javascript.

guides/database/migrations#creating-your.title: Creating Your First Migration
nodes: Let's begin by executing the following ace command to create a new migration file.
AdonisJS uses the compiled Javascript code for running migrations. So make sure that you are compiling your project in a separate terminal window using node ace serve --watch command.
Open the newly created file inside the text editor and replace its content with the following code snippet.
Migrations are executed against the compiled Javascript code. So, make sure to run one of the following ace commands to keep the compiled output upto date.
Finally, run the following ace command to execute the instructions for creating the users table.
Congratulations! You have just created and executed your first migration. If you re-run the same command, Lucid will not execute the migration file, since it has already been executed.

guides/database/migrations#how-it-works.title: How it works?
nodes: The
make:migration
command creates a new migration file prefixed with the timestamp. The timestamp is important, because the migrations are executed in the ascending order by name.
Migration files are not only limited to creating a new table. You can also
alter
table, define database triggers and so on.
The
migration:run
command executes all the pending migrations. Pending migrations are those, which are never executed using
migration:run
command.
A migration file is either in a
pending
state or in
completed
state.
Once a migration file has been successfully executed, it will be tracked inside the
adonis_schema
database table to avoid running it for multiple times.

guides/database/migrations#changing-exis.title: Changing Existing Migrations
nodes: Occasionally you will make mistakes when writing a migration. If you have already run the migration using migration:run command, then you cannot just edit the file and re-run it, since the file has been tracked under the list of completed migrations.

Instead, you can rollback the migration by running the migration:rollback command. Assuming the previously created migration file already exists, running the rollback command will drop the users table.

guides/database/migrations#how-rollback-.title: How rollback works?
nodes: Every migration class has two methods,
up
and
down
. The
down
is called during the rollback process.
You (the developer) is responsible for writing correct instructions to undo the changes made by the
up
method. For example: If
up
method creates a table, then the
down
method must drop it.
After rollback, Lucid considers the migration file as pending and running
migration:run
will re-run it. So you can modify this file and then re-run it.

guides/database/migrations#avoiding-roll.title: Avoiding Rollbacks
nodes: Performing a rollback during development is perfectly fine, since there is no fear of data loss. However, performing a rollback in production is not really an option in majority of cases. Consider this example:
You create and run a migration to setup the
users
table.
Overtime this table has received data, since the app is running in production.
Your product has evolved and now you want to add a new column to the
users
table.
You cannot simply rollback, edit the existing migration and then re-run it, because, the rollback will drop the
users
table.
Instead, you create a new migration file to alter the existing users table by adding the required column. In other words, migrations should always move forward.

guides/database/migrations#alter-example.title: Alter example
nodes: Following is an example of creating a new migration to alter the existing table.
Make Migration
Migration

guides/database/migrations#migrations-co.title: Migrations Config
nodes: The configuration for migrations is stored inside the config/database.ts file under the connection config object.
Instructions inside a migration file are wrapped inside a database transaction. You can disable the use of transactions by setting
disableTransactions = true
You can define multiple
paths
from which to read the migrations files. The migrations are executed in sequence of the defined paths.
The
tableName
property allows you to customize the table name for tracking completed migrations.
Since rollbacks can lead to data loss, you can disable them in production by setting
disableRollbacksInProduction = true

guides/database/factories.title: Model factories
nodes: Have you ever written tests, in which the first 15-20 lines of each test are dedicated to just setting up the database state by using multiple models? With model factories, you can extract all this setup to a dedicated file and then write the bare minimum code to setup the database state.
By the end of this guide, you will know:
How to create and use factories
How to define factory states
Working with model relationships
Using the faker API to generate and use random data

guides/database/factories#creating-facto.title: Creating factories
nodes: Model factories are stored inside databases/factories directory. You can define all factories within a single file or create dedicated files for each model, the choice is yours.
Unlike seeders or models, the factories are declarative in nature as shown in the following example:
The
Factory.define
method accepts a total of two arguments.
The first argument is reference to the Lucid model.

The second argument is a callback that returns an object of properties to be used when persisting the model instance. Make sure that you return an object with all the required properties, otherwise the database will raise
not null
exceptions.
Finally, make sure to call the
build
method.

guides/database/factories#using-factorie.title: Using factories
nodes: Using factories is quite simple. Just import the file and use the exported factories.
In order to create multiple instances, you can make use of the createMany method.

guides/database/factories#merging-attrib.title: Merging attributes
nodes: You can override the default set of attributes using the .merge method. For example:
When creating multiple instances, you can define an array of attributes and they will merge based upon their indices. For example:
In the above example
The first user will have the email of
foo@example.com
The second user will have the email of
bar@example.com
And, the third user will use the default email address, since the merge array has a length of 2.

guides/database/factories#factory-states.title: Factory states
nodes: Factory states allow you to define variations of your factories as states. For example: On a Post factory, you can have different states to represent published and draft posts.
By default, all posts will be created with DRAFT status. However, you can explicitly apply the published state to create posts with PUBLISHED status.

guides/database/factories#relationships.title: Relationships
nodes: Model factories makes it super simple to work with relationships. Consider the following example:
Now, you can create a user and its posts all together in one call.

guides/database/factories#points-to-note.title: Points to note
nodes: The factory will find the type of relationship by inspecting the Lucid model. For example: If your model defines a
hasMany
relationship on
posts
, then factory will infer the same.
A relationship first needs to be defined on the model and then only it can be defined on the Factory.
Lucid will internally wrap all the database operations inside a transaction. So if a relationship persistance fails, the parent model persistance will be rolled back too.

guides/database/factories#applying-relat.title: Applying relationship states
nodes: You can also apply states on a relationship by passing a callback to the with method.
Similarly, if you want, you can create few posts with the published state and few without it.
Finally, you can also create nested relationships. For example: Create a user with two posts and five comments for each post.

guides/database/factories#stubbing-datab.title: Stubbing database calls
nodes: In some cases, you may prefer to stub out the database calls and just want to create in-memory model instances. This is can achieved using the makeStubbed and makeStubbedMany methods.
The stubbed calls will never hit the database and will assign an in-memory numeric id to the model instances.

guides/database/factories#customizing-st.title: Customizing stub id
nodes: When we say id. We mean the primary key of a model and not a fixed named attribute id.
The stub id is just an in-memory counter, that keeps on increasing with every call. If required, you can define a custom method to generate stub ids in a different manner.
For example: Generating ids as a BigInt when using PostgreSQL bigInteger data type.
You can make use of the makeStubbed hook to customize the id generation behavior for an individual factory.

guides/database/factories#runtime-contex.title: Runtime context
nodes: Every time you create a model instance from a factory, a runtime context is also created at the same time. The context is then passed to all the hooks, the define method callback and also the relationships.
Most of the time, you just want to access the faker object from the context. However, following are the available properties.
isStubbed
: A boolean to know, if the factory was instantiated in stub mode.
$trx
: A transaction object, under which all the database operations are wrapped. If you are running any database queries inside the factory hooks, then make sure to also wrap them inside the transaction.
Following is an example showcasing the callbacks that receives the runtime context (ctx).

guides/database/factories#hooks.title: Hooks
nodes: The factory exposes the following hooks to perform actions before or after certain events. You can also define multiple hooks for a single event.
before create Invoked before the insert query.
after create Invoked after the insert query.
before makeStubbed Invoked before the stubbed call.
after makeStubbed Invoked after the stubbed call.
after make Invoked only after the model instance has been created. This hook is also invoked before the before create and before makeStubbed hooks.

guides/database/factories#custom-connect.title: Custom connections
nodes: Factories allows you to define a custom connection or query client at the time using them. For example:
Also, you can pass a custom query client instance.
For the sake of API uniformity among the factories and the Lucid models, you can also define the connection or the client using the query method.

guides/database/factories#customizations.title: Customizations
nodes: Finally, you can optionally customize the behavior of certain operations performed under the hood.

guides/database/factories#newup.title: newUp
nodes: By defining the newUp handler, you can customize the process of instantiating a model instance for a given factory.

guides/database/factories#merge.title: merge
nodes: By defining the merge handler, you can customize the merge behavior.

guides/database/seeds.title: Database seeding
nodes: Database seeding is a way to setup your application with some initial data that is required to run and use the application. For example:
Creating a seeder to insert countries, states and cities before deploying and running your application.
Or a seeder to insert users inside the database for local development.
In AdonisJS, the seeders are stored inside the database/seeders directory. You can create seeders manually or run the following ace command to create one for you.
The seeder file is a standard Javascript class as shown in the following example:
As you can see, the
UserSeeder
is a standard Javascript class extending the
BaseSeeder
Within the
run
method, you can execute the database operations.

guides/database/seeds#running-seeders.title: Running seeders
nodes: You can execute all or selected database seeders as shown below:
There is also an interactive mode to manually select one or more seeders to execute.

guides/database/seeds#development-only-s.title: Development only seeders
nodes: Lucid allows you to mark your certain seeder files to be available only during the development phase. This ensures that by mistake you are not seeding your production database with dummy data.
The developmentOnly flag ensures that this file is only executed when process.env.NODE_ENV = 'development'.

guides/database/seeds#idempotent-operati.title: Idempotent operations
nodes: Unlike migrations, there is no tracking system in place for the database seeders. In other words, executing a seeder multiple times will perform the inserts multiple times as well.
Based upon the nature of a seeder, you may or may not want this behavior. For example:
It is okay to run a
PostSeeder
for multiple times and increase the number of posts you have in the database.
On the other hand, you would want the
CountrySeeder
to perform inserts only once. These kind of seeders are idempotent in nature.

Fortunately, Lucid models has inbuilt support for idempotent operations using methods like updateOrCreate or fetchOrCreateMany. Continuing with the CountrySeeder, following is an example of creating countries only once.

In the above example, the updateOrCreateMany method will look for existing rows inside the database using the isoCode code and only inserts the missing ones and hence running the CountrySeeder for multiple times will not insert duplicate rows.
Learn more about the other idempotent methods here.

guides/database/seeds#customizing-databa.title: Customizing database connection
nodes: The db:seed command accepts an optional --connection flag and forwards it to the seeder files as a connection property. From there on, you can use this property to set the appropriate connection during your models interactions. For example:
Now you can specify the --connection flag on your db:seed command and the UserSeeder will use it.

guides/security/introduction.title: Introduction
nodes: Keeping the security at the forefront, AdonisJS ships with a bunch of tools to make sure that your applications are secure from common vulnerabilities.
Along with all the tooling, we regularly audit the dependencies used by the framework core and the first party plugins.

guides/security/introduction#free-from-p.title: Free from prototype poisoning
nodes: The JSON.parse method is vulnerable to the prototype poisoning and can potentially force your applications to mis-behave.
The JSON objects accepted over the HTTP requests by your AdonisJS applications are carefully parsed to protect your code from prototype poisoning.

guides/security/password-hashing.title: Password Hashing
nodes: AdonisJS uses the industry standard algorithms bcrypt and argon2 to hash user passwords. Hashing is not same as encryption, since the hashed value cannot be converted back to original value and hence highly recommended for storing passwords.

guides/security/password-hashing#availab.title: Available drivers
nodes: AdonisJS out of the box comes with the support for bcrypt and argon2. However, you must install their respective drivers for npm.
Run
npm i @phc/bcrypt
for bcrypt.
And
npm i @phc/argon2
for argon2.
The configuration for the hash module is stored inside the config/hash.ts file. Feel free to tweak it as per your requirements.

guides/security/password-hashing#hashing.title: Hashing values
nodes: Following is an example of creating a hash of a value.

guides/security/password-hashing#verify-.title: Verify against the existing hash
nodes: As stated earlier, you cannot convert the hash back to its original value. However, you can verify the plain value against the existing hash.

guides/security/password-hashing#switchi.title: Switching drivers
nodes: You can switch between drivers using the use method.

guides/security/password-hashing#hash-us.title: Hash user password
nodes: In order to hash the user password, you can make use of the Lucid models hooks and hash it before creating the user record or before updating their password.
Following is an example of the model hook

guides/validator/introduction.title: Introduction
nodes: AdonisJS comes with an in-built data validation library to validate form requests using a pre-defined schema. Since, the support for validations is baked-in to the framework, there is no need to install any additional libraries.
The AdonisJS validator has support for:
Async validations
Validating nested objects and arrays
Custom messages & Error reporters
No need to maintain separate interfaces for intellisense to work
Removes non-validated properties from the data object
Extensible API to add custom rules

guides/validator/introduction#built-with.title: Built with HTTP in mind
nodes: The data submitted over the HTTP is always represented as string and hence manual data casting is required to convert it to language specific data types. For example:
As you can see in the above video, the value of marks is a string and not a number. Now, if a validator is strict with data types, it will offload the work of type casting on you.
However, AdonisJS addresses this behavior and takes care of the type casting for you by inferring types from the validation schema. For example:

guides/validator/introduction#custom-err.title: Custom error messages
nodes: The validator has first class support for defining custom error messages. The validate method accepts an object of messages along side the validation schema.
Mostly custom messages are defined as a combination of the
field name
validation rule
. For example:
marks.required
. However, you can define global messages for just the validation rules.
You can reference runtime values within the validation messages using curly braces.
To write messages for nested properties, you can rely on the dot notation. For example:
user.profile.username

guides/validator/introduction#type-infor.title: Type information
nodes: The static types are extracted automatically from the runtime validation rules, hence there is no need to maintain separate interfaces just for the type information or intellisense to work.

guides/validator/introduction#extensible.title: Extensible
nodes: Just like every other part of the framework. The validator is built with extensibility in mind and exposes the API to add custom validation rules. For example: Here's the source code of Lucid extending the validator to add the database related validation rules.

guides/validator/usage.title: Usage
nodes: In this guide, we will take a glimpse of the AdonisJS validator by covering only the basics and later, you can deep dive into individual topics to have a stronger understanding.
By the end of this guide, you will know:
How to validate form requests during an HTTP request
How to use validator outside the flow of an HTTP request
Covering the basics of validation schema
This guide only cover inline validation. If you'd like to create a validator class, you should refer to the form submissions guide.

guides/validator/usage#validating-http-r.title: Validating HTTP requests
nodes: Most of the times, you will be using the validator to validate the forms submitted over an HTTP request. So, lets begin with an HTTP specific example first and later we will see how to use the validator directly.
First, you need to import the
schema
object from
@ioc:Adonis/Core/Validator
module.
Next, you have to define the validation schema using the
schema.create
method and define all the properties you want to validate.
Finally, using the
request.validate
method, you can validate the request form data against the pre-define schema.
If validation passes, then the return value of the request.validate will contain all the validated properties, otherwise an exception will be raised.

guides/validator/usage#handling-errors.title: Handling Errors
nodes: Upon failure, the request.validate method will raise an exception, containing the error messages. One option is self handle the exception and convert it into a response. For example:
Another (recommended) approach is to let AdonisJS handle the exception for you and convert it into a response. So let's understand how that will work.
The core of the framework allows exceptions to self handle themselves during an HTTP request. You can learn more about it in
exception handling guide
Once, the validator will handle its own exception, it will convert the error messages to an HTTP response as explained below:
If
Accept: application/json
request header exists. It will return back a JSON response.
If
Accept: application/vnd.api+json
request header exists. It will return back a JSON response formatted as per the
JSON API spec
Otherwise, the request will be redirected back to the previous page and error messages are forwarded back as
flash messages

guides/validator/usage#standalone-usage.title: Standalone usage
nodes: You can also use the validator outside of the HTTP requests. Following is an example of the same.
With standalone usage, you will have to wrap your validation calls inside a try/catch statement, since the self handled exceptions only work during within HTTP request lifecycle.

guides/validator/usage#schema-101.title: Schema 101
nodes: The schema definition is divided into three main parts.
The shape of the expected data defined using
(schema.create())
The expected data type of individual properties, ie
(schema.string())
Additional set of validation rules to validate the data formatting, or checking if its unique in the database.

Also, if you look carefully, we have separated the format validations from core data types. For example: There is no data type called schema.email. In fact email is a standalone rule to check the formatting a string.

This separation helps a lot in extending the validator with custom rules, without creating unnecessary schema types that has no meaning. For example: There is no thing called email type, it is a just a string, formatted as an email.

guides/validator/usage#marking-fields-as.title: Marking fields as optional
nodes: Every schema field is marked as required by default. However, you can mark them optional by chaining the .optional method. For example:
You can chain the .optional method with all available schema data types.
So, here we are saying, the content property must be defined as a string, but its okay if it is not defined at all.

guides/validator/usage#validating-nested.title: Validating nested objects/arrays
nodes: You can define schema for a nested object using the schema.object data type. For example:
Similarly, you can validate an array using the schema.array data type.

guides/validator/usage#validating-array-.title: Validating array length
nodes: You can make use of the additional validation rules to enforce a minimum or a maximum array length. For example:

guides/validator/usage#whats-next.title: What's next?
nodes: We hope, the usage guide gave a head start with the validator. However, we do recommend reading the following guides to explore all available data types and validation rules.
Available
schema data types
List of available
validation rules
Custom messages

guides/validator/schema-types.title: Schema Types
nodes: Schema types enforces type validation on a given property. Also, every schema type has a static return data type as well. In other words, there is no need to maintain separate interfaces for Typescript types.
In this guide, we will go through all of the available schema types and the options accepted by them.

guides/validator/schema-types#schemastri.title: schema.string
nodes: Enforces the value to a valid string. Also, you can pass options to trim the whitespace or escape certain characters with HTML entities.
The <, >, &, ', " and / characters will be escaped with HTML entities.

guides/validator/schema-types#passing-ad.title: Passing additional rules
nodes: You can pass an array of additional rules as 2nd argument.

guides/validator/schema-types#schemanumb.title: schema.number
nodes: Enforces the value to be a valid number. The string representation of a number will be casted to a number data type. For example: "22" becomes 22.

guides/validator/schema-types#passing-ad.title: Passing additional rules
nodes: Since the number rule does not accept any configuration options, you can pass additional rules as 1st argument itself.

guides/validator/schema-types#schemabool.title: schema.boolean
nodes: Enforces the value to be a valid boolean. The following literal values are also casted to a boolean.
"on"
"true"
is casted to
true
"off"
"false"
is casted to
false
We cast on and off values to a boolean, since the HTML form input[type="checkbox"] sets the value to "on" if checkbox is checked.

guides/validator/schema-types#schemadate.title: schema.date
nodes: Enforces the value to be a valid date object or a string representing a date. The values are casted to an instance of luxon.DateTime
You can also enforce a format for the string values by defining a valid format accepted by luxon.
Or use the following shorthand codes for standardized date/time formats.

guides/validator/schema-types#schemaenum.title: schema.enum
nodes: Enforces value to be one of the pre-defined enum options.
You can also make use of Typescript enums.
If you are caching your validation schema using the cacheKey and your enum options relies on a runtime value, then you must make use of refs.

guides/validator/schema-types#schemaenum.title: schema.enumSet
nodes: The schema.enumSet is similar to the enum, instead it accepts an array of values that falls under one of the pre-defined values.
In the following example, we expect the user to select one or more of the pre-defined skills.
If you are caching your validation schema using the cacheKey and your enumSet options relies on a runtime value, then you must make use of refs.

guides/validator/schema-types#schemafile.title: schema.file
nodes: Enforces the value to be a valid uploaded file. You can also enforce additional validation rules on the file size and the extension names.

guides/validator/schema-types#schemaarra.title: schema.array
nodes: Enforces the value to be a valid Javascript array.
You can also validate the members of the array, using the .members method. For example: We can enforce all members of the array are numbers.
To validate the array itself, you can pass additional validation rules to the array method.
A good example would be to validate number of files to be uploaded through HTML form.

guides/validator/schema-types#schemaobje.title: schema.object
nodes: Enforces the value to be a valid Javascript object. Similar to an array, you can also validate the members/properties of an object.
To accept an object with any/unknown properties, you can make use of the anyMembers method.

guides/validator/rules.title: Validation Rules
nodes: Validation rules allows adding additional constraints on the schema types. For example: A rule to validate the formatting of a string to be a valid email, and another rule to ensure a field value is unique inside the database.

guides/validator/rules#importing-and-usi.title: Importing and using rules
nodes: The first step is to import the rules list.
And then define them on the schema types.

guides/validator/rules#rulesalpha.title: rules.alpha
nodes: Enforces the value to only have letters. Optionally, you can also allow spaces, dash and underscore characters.
Can only be used only with the string schema type.

guides/validator/rules#rulesconfirmed.title: rules.confirmed
nodes: Enforce the field under validation is also confirmed using the _confirmation convention. You will mostly use this rule for password confirmation.
The confirmed rule also allows you to use a custom confirmation field name.

guides/validator/rules#rulesdistinct.title: rules.distinct
nodes: The distinct rule ensures that all values of a property inside an array are unique.
Assuming you have an array of objects, each defining a product id property and you want to ensure that no duplicates product ids are being used.
You can also use the distinct rule with an array of literal values by using the wildcard * keyword. For example:

guides/validator/rules#rulesemail.title: rules.email
nodes: Enforces the value to be properly formatted as an email.
Can only be used only with the string schema type.
You can also define the following options to control the validation behavior.
allowIpDomain false Set it as true to allow IP addresses in the host part.
ignoreMaxLength false Set it as true to disable email address max length validation.
domainSpecificValidation false Set it as true to dis-allow certain syntactically valid email addresses that are rejected by GMail
sanitize false Not a validation option, but instead can be used to transform the local part of the email (before the @ symbol) to all lowercase.

guides/validator/rules#rulesexists.title: rules.exists
nodes: Enforces the value to exist in a database table.
The validation rule is added by @adonisjs/lucid package. So make sure it is installed and configured, before using this rule.

guides/validator/rules#case-insensitivit.title: Case insensitivity
nodes: Many databases perform case sensitive queries. So whether you can transform the value to lowerCase in JavaScript or make use of the caseInsensitive option to convert value to lowercase during the query.

guides/validator/rules#additional-constr.title: Additional constraints
nodes: Additionally, you can also define where and whereNot constraints. For example: Limit the database query to a specific tenant id.
If you are caching your validation schema using the cacheKey and your where constraints relies on a runtime value, then you must make use of refs.
Example with refs.

guides/validator/rules#rulesunique.title: rules.unique
nodes: The rules.unique method is the opposite of rules.exists method. Instead of checking the existence of the value in a given table, it ensures the value doesn't exists.
The validation rule is added by @adonisjs/lucid package. So make sure it is installed and configured, before using this rule.

guides/validator/rules#rulesip.title: rules.ip
nodes: Enforce the field under validation is a valid ip address. Optionally, you can also specify the ip version.

guides/validator/rules#rulesmaxlength.title: rules.maxLength
nodes: Limit the max length of a string or an array.
You can also apply the maxLength rule on an array.

guides/validator/rules#rulesminlength.title: rules.minLength
nodes: Enforce minimum length on a string or an array.

guides/validator/rules#rulesunsigned.title: rules.unsigned
nodes: Ensure, the value is an unsigned integer

guides/validator/rules#rulesrange.title: rules.range
nodes: Ensure, the value is contained in the specified range.

guides/validator/rules#rulesregex.title: rules.regex
nodes: Define a custom regex to validate the value against.

guides/validator/rules#rulesuuid.title: rules.uuid
nodes: Enforce the value of field under validation is a valid uuid. You can also optionally enforce a uuid version.

guides/validator/rules#rulesmobile.title: rules.mobile
nodes: Enforces the value to be properly formatted as a phone number. You can also define locales for country specific validation.
Validate against selected locales
Also, you can enable strict mode, which will force the end user to specify the country code along with the + prefix.

guides/validator/rules#rulesrequiredifex.title: rules.requiredIfExists
nodes: Mark the current field as required, when another field exists and contains some value.

guides/validator/rules#rulesrequiredifex.title: rules.requiredIfExistsAll
nodes: Mark the current field as required, when all of the other fields exists and contains some value.

guides/validator/rules#rulesrequiredifex.title: rules.requiredIfExistsAny
nodes: Mark the current field as required, when any of the other fields exists and contains some value.

guides/validator/rules#rulesrequiredifno.title: rules.requiredIfNotExists
nodes: The opposite of rules.requiredIfExists

guides/validator/rules#rulesrequiredifno.title: rules.requiredIfNotExistsAll
nodes: The opposite of rules.requiredIfExistsAll

guides/validator/rules#rulesrequiredifno.title: rules.requiredIfNotExistsAny
nodes: The opposite of rules.requiredIfExistsAny

guides/validator/rules#rulesrequiredwhen.title: rules.requiredWhen
nodes: Mark the current field as required, when the value of the other field matches a given criteria.
The requiredWhen rule support the following operators.
in
notIn

guides/validator/rules#rulesafter.title: rules.after
nodes: Ensure, the value of field is after a given date/offset. The rule can be only be used with the date data type.
The after method can receive one of the following values:
The duration and the offset. Feel free to use Typescript intellisense for finding the available offset keywords.
The today or tomorrow keywords.
Finally, you can also pass an instance of luxon DateTime object. Make sure, you pass it is a ref.

guides/validator/rules#rulesbefore.title: rules.before
nodes: Similar to rules.after but instead enforces the value be before the defined date/offset.

guides/validator/rules#rulesafterfield.title: rules.afterField
nodes: Similar to the after rule. But instead of defining a date/offset for comparison, you define the field to check against. For example:
Also, you can make use of the afterOrEqualToField for enforcing date to be same or after the given field.

guides/validator/rules#rulesbeforefield.title: rules.beforeField
nodes: Similar to the before rule. But instead of defining a date/offset for comparison, you define the field to check against. For example:
Also, you can make use of the beforeOrEqualToField for enforcing date to be same or before the given field.

guides/validator/rules#rulesblacklist.title: rules.blacklist
nodes: Enforce the value of field is not inside the blacklist. The blacklist rule is opposite of the enum schema type

guides/validator/rules#rulesurl.title: rules.url
nodes: Ensure the field under validation is a valid URL.
Along with the format validation, you can also enforce the url to be from a certain domain. For example:
Or use the hostBlacklist option to disallow certain hosts.

guides/validator/rules#validation-option.title: Validation options
nodes: Following is the list of all the validation options.

guides/validator/rules#normalization-opt.title: Normalization options
nodes: Along with the validation, you can also use the following options to normalize urls.
The
ensureProtocol
will make sure that all URLs after validation have the
https
protocol.
The
stripWWW
option will remove the
www
from the URL.

guides/validator/custom-messages.title: Custom Messages
nodes: Once you get the validations working, the next natural step is to present helpful error messages to the end user. In this guide, we will go through the API to define custom messages.

guides/validator/custom-messages#definin.title: Defining custom messages
nodes: Both, the request.validate and the validator.validate methods accepts an optional messages object containing a set of custom messages.
As you can see, the messages are defined as a combination of field + the validation rule and this enables you to define unique and specific messages for each field.
However, you can also define generic messages just for the validation rules. For example:
Validator will first look for the
field.rule
messages.
Next, it will look for just
rule
messages.
Finally, it will fallback to a generic message.

guides/validator/custom-messages#message.title: Messages API
nodes: To make sure that you are applications are not getting bom-bared with ton of custom messages. Validator has support for dynamic messages with the help of wild card callback and micro templating.

guides/validator/custom-messages#micro-t.title: Micro templating
nodes: The message string cans define placeholders for runtime values as shown in the following code snippet.
Following is the list of placeholders, you can define inside your messages.
{{ field }}
: Name of the field under validation. Nested object paths are represented with a
dot separator
. For example:
user.profile.username
{{ rule }}
: Name of the validation rule.
{{ options }}
: The options passed by the validation methods. For example: The enum rule will pass an array of
choices
and some rules may not pass any options.

guides/validator/custom-messages#wild-ca.title: Wild card callback
nodes: You can also define a wildcard callback, that is executed to retrieve the message string for every single validation message.
The wildcard callback can be used in combination with regular messages. In the following example, the wildcard callback will be invoked only for the messages not defined in the object.

guides/validator/custom-messages#options.title: Options passed to the message string
nodes: Following is the list of options passed by the different validation methods to the message string.

guides/validator/custom-messages#date.title: date
nodes: The date validation rule will pass the options.format.

guides/validator/custom-messages#distinc.title: distinct
nodes: The distinct validation rule will pass the field on which the distinct rule is applied, along with index at which the duplicate value was found.

guides/validator/custom-messages#enum--e.title: enum / enumSet
nodes: The enum and enumSet validation rules will pass an array of options.choices.

guides/validator/custom-messages#file.title: file
nodes: The file validation allows defining custom messages for the sub rules. For example:

guides/validator/custom-messages#minleng.title: minLength / maxLength
nodes: The minLength and maxLength validation rules will pass the options.length to the message.

guides/validator/custom-messages#require.title: requiredIfExists / requiredIfNotExists
nodes: The requiredIfExists and requiredIfNotExists validation rules will pass the options.otherField as a string.

guides/validator/custom-messages#conditi.title: Conditional required rules
nodes: The following requiredIf* rules will pass the options.otherFields as an array of strings.
requiredIfExistsAll
requiredIfExistsAny
requiredIfNotExistsAll
requiredIfNotExistsAny

guides/validator/custom-messages#require.title: requiredWhen
nodes: The requiredWhen validation rule will pass the following options.
options.otherField
options.operator
options.values

guides/validator/error-reporters.title: Error Reporters
nodes: Validation error messages are consumed by many different parts of your application. You may use them at the time of rendering the Edge template or you may want to pass it to frontend client from your REST API server.
In other words, you will want different representation of the same error messages, based upon the consumer of your app. For example:
The Edge templates just want an array of messages in reference to a form field name.
A
JSONAPI
spec complaint server should return the error messages as per the
spec
Or, maybe you want to render them as XML.
If validation error messages always had a fixed shape, then you will have to manually loop over them for restructuring. Luckily, not with error reporter.

guides/validator/error-reporters#definin.title: Defining reporter
nodes: The validator.validate or request.validate methods optionally accepts a reporter to format the error messages. You can pass one of the pre-bundled reporters or a custom one.

guides/validator/error-reporters#api-err.title: API Error Reporter
nodes: You must use the api reporter, when creating an API server and not following any particular spec. Following is an example of the error message formatted using the api reporter.

guides/validator/error-reporters#jsonapi.title: JSONAPI error reporter
nodes: The jsonapi error reporter will format error messages as per the JSON API spec. Following is an example of the same

guides/validator/error-reporters#web-err.title: Web error reporter
nodes: The web reporter must be used by server rendered applications. The error reporter redirects back to the form along with error messages stored as session flash messages.
We recommend reading the form submission guide to understand the flow

guides/validator/error-reporters#content.title: Content Negotiation
nodes: The request.validate method uses the content negotiation to choose the most appropriate error formatter for a given HTTP request.
If the
Accept = 'application/vnd.api+json'
header is set, the
jsonapi
error reporter will be used.
For
Accept = 'application/json'
header, the
api
error reporter will be used.
For everything else, the
web
error reporter will be used.

guides/validator/error-reporters#creatin.title: Creating your own error reporter
nodes: Creating your own error reporter is very simple, you just need to adhere to the ErrorReporterContract interface.
Create a new file app/Validators/Reporters/MyReporter.ts and paste the following contents inside it.
Now, you can import this file and assign it to the reporter property.

guides/validator/schema-caching.title: Schema Caching
nodes: The schema created using schema.create method is first complied to an executable function and then executed to validate the data against the defined rules.

The compilation process does takes some time (1ms to 2ms) before the validation begins. Based upon the performance expectations you have, you may want to consider caching the compiled schema and hence don't pay the compilation penalty on every request.

guides/validator/schema-caching#using-th.title: Using the cacheKey
nodes: Caching a schema is straightforward, you just need to define a unique cacheKey during the request.validate call.
It is recommended to use ctx.routeKey over request.url() as the cache key. Since, your application can have two same URLs using different HTTP methods and hence their schemas will conflict.
The first call to
request.validate
will compile the schema and saves the output in reference to the
cacheKey
Until the
cacheKey
is same, the schema won't be compiled again.

guides/validator/schema-caching#caching-.title: Caching caveats
nodes: Caching in any form is not free and same is the case with the schema caching. If your schema relies on runtime values, then caching schema will not give desired outcome. Consider the following example:
You are creating a form that accepts the user
state
and their
city
The city options are based upon the value of the selected
state

If you look at the above example, the enum options for the city are dependent on the selectedState and will vary with every HTTP request. Hence, there is no simple way to cache the schema with a fixed key.

guides/validator/schema-caching#option-1.title: Option 1 (Give up caching)
nodes: The first option is to give up caching. This will add a delay of couple of milliseconds to your requests, but gives you the simplest API to use to runtime values within your schema definition.

guides/validator/schema-caching#option-2.title: Option 2 (Create a unique key)
nodes: Considering the above example, you can append the selected state to the cacheKey and hence each state will have its own copy of cache schema. For example:

The above approach has its own set of downsides. If there are 37 states, then there will be 37 cached copies of the same schema with a small variation. Also, this number will grow exponentially if you need more than one dynamic value.
In fact, giving up caching is better than caching too many schemas with small variations.

guides/validator/schema-caching#option-3.title: Option 3 (Using refs)
nodes: Refs gives you the best of the both worlds. You can still cache your schema and also reference the runtime values inside them. Following is an example of the same:
Instead of referencing CITIES[this.selectedState] directly, you move it to the schema.refs object and from there on, the cities will be picked up at runtime without re-compiling the schema.
Refs only work if the validation rule or the schema type supports them.

guides/validator/custom-rules.title: Custom Rules
nodes: The validator is extensible and allows adding custom rules. In this guide, we will go through the validator API and add a couple of custom rules to understand the different moving parts.

guides/validator/custom-rules#validating.title: Validating phone numbers
nodes: Lets add a custom rule to validate phone numbers using libphonenumber-js. The validator already ships with a mobile number validation rule, but the libphonenumber-js is more robust.
Lets begin by creating a new preload file using the following ace command. Make sure to select During HTTP server, since we do not want to load the rules while running an ace command.
Open the newly created file and paste the following code snippet inside it.
We skip the validation when field value is not a string.
We parse the field value using the
parsePhoneNumberFromString
method.
If the value is null or is invalid, then we will report the validation error using the
errorReporter.report
method.

guides/validator/custom-rules#updating-i.title: Updating interface for static analysis to work
nodes: Next, you also need to update the Rules interface for typescript to recognize the rule at compile time.
Create a new file contracts/validator.ts file and paste the following code snippet inside it.

guides/validator/custom-rules#usage.title: Usage
nodes: Alright, now you can use the phone validation rule inside your validators. For example:

guides/validator/custom-rules#accepting-.title: Accepting options
nodes: Right now the country code is hardcoded inside the validation method. Let's take a step ahead and make it configurable by accepting it as an option.
This time, we will approach the change from our interface. Re-open contracts/validator.ts file and update the phone method.
We accept a required options object with only one property
countryCode
By using an object, we allow ourselves to accept more configuration options in the future.
Next, update the schema usage and pass the country code explicitly.

guides/validator/custom-rules#updating-i.title: Updating implementation to handle options
nodes: Finally, we need to update our rule implementation to use the configured country code over the hardcoded one.
The options accepted by a validation method are passed an array of multiple arguments to the rule implementation.
In our case, we accept only one argument. i.e: An object with the
countryCode
property. So our implementation receives it as an array with just one item inside it.
Finally, we remove the hard coded
IN
country code and use the one received as an option.

guides/validator/custom-rules#mutating-v.title: Mutating values
nodes: The validator allows custom rules to also mutate the field value, since we believe that validation and normalization/sanitization always goes hand in hand.
The phone number rule is a great example of where you would like to perform normalization before storing it inside the database.
One option is to separate the normalization and validation processes, which sounds great in theory, but can have huge impact on the performance of your app.
Let's imagine the phone number is a deeply nested property inside an array and then sub-objects.
First, you will loop over all the items to validate the phone number.
And then again run a loop to normalize its value.
To address this concern, we allow you to normalize and mutate the value during validation itself.

guides/validator/custom-rules#normalizin.title: Normalizing the phone number
nodes: Lets update the rule implementation to normalize the phone number and then mutate its value.
We use the
formatNation
method to format the phone number.
Next, we make use of the
mutate
method to set the new value.
Now, all validated phone numbers will always be formatted.

guides/validator/custom-rules#reporting-.title: Reporting errors
nodes: In the earlier versions of the validator, we used to return boolean values from the validation functions to indicate the success or failure. However, the boolean are very restrictive in nature. For example:
You cannot report multiple errors.
You cannot pass custom metadata related to the validation failure.
You cannot report errors for sub validation failures. For example: The
file
validation rule reports separate errors for
.size
and
.extnames
failures.
To address the above concern, we now pass the error reporter to the validation rules giving them the complete control.
Following is an example of the report method arguments.

guides/validator/custom-rules#pointer.title: pointer
nodes: The pointeris the complete path to the field under validation. If a field is inside a nested object, then the pointer will be complete path joined using dot.
Pointer for username will be user.profile.username.

guides/validator/custom-rules#rulename.title: ruleName
nodes: The ruleName is the rule for which the validation has failed. This value doesn't have to be strictly the rule name. For example: The file validation rule uses file.size and file.extnames as the ruleName.
This allows custom messages to have more variations.

guides/validator/custom-rules#defaultmes.title: defaultMessage
nodes: The message to use, when no custom message is defined.

guides/validator/custom-rules#arraypoint.title: arrayPointer
nodes: The validator allows defining custom messages for array children using the wildcard * keyword. For example:
The arrayPointer is a string using the * keyword, making it easier for the error reporter to locate custom messages for field defined inside an array.

guides/validator/custom-rules#metadata.title: metaData
nodes: Meta data is an optional object that you can pass to the error reporter, that inturn can be used by the custom messages. For example:
Now, the countryCode is accessible inside the custom message as follows:

guides/validator/custom-rules#referencin.title: Referencing other field's values
nodes: At times, you would want to write validation rules, that relies on other fields to run the validation.
In the following example, the requiredIfExists validation rule first checks for the username before enforcing the required validation on the password field.
Now, if you are creating a rule with similar behavior, you can access the value of other fields as shown in the following example:

guides/validator/custom-rules#what-is-ro.title: What is root and tip?
nodes: The root is the original data object passed to the validator.validate method. And, the tip is the closest parent object of the current field.
Given the following data object (root).
The validation function is executed for the username property, the tip will the following object.
We maintain a reference to the tip, so that we are not performing nested lookups for multiple properties of the same object and for multiple validation rules applied on a single property.
So, now as you know about the root and the tip properties, you need to pass these values to the helpers.getFieldValue method and it will lookup the value for you.

guides/views/introduction.title: Introduction
nodes: AdonisJS uses Edge as its template engine. It is a fully featured template engine written for the modern day. It has out of the box support for:
Conditionals and loops
Components, layouts and partials
Runtime debugging using Chrome DevTools
Stack traces that points to the original filename and the line number
Extensible API to add your own custom Edge tags

guides/views/introduction#setup.title: Setup
nodes: Edge comes pre-installed with the Web Application project structure created using the create-adonis-ts-app binary. However, installing it separately is also pretty straight forward.
Open the .adonisrc.json file to check if it is installed and registered under the providers array or not.
If not, then follow the below instructions to install it from the npm package registry.
npm
yarn
Once installed, run the following ace command to setup the package.

guides/views/introduction#usage.title: Usage
nodes: Lets begin by creating a route that renders a given template file.

Next step is to create the home.edge template. Template lives inside the resources/views directory of your project root. You can manually create a file inside this folder, or use the following ace command to create one.
Let's open the newly created file and paste the following code snippet inside it.
Make sure to start the development server by running node ace serve --watch and visit http://localhost:3333 to view the contents of the template file.

guides/views/introduction#how-it-works.title: How it works?
nodes: Every route handler receives an instance of
view
that is used to render template files.
The
view.render
method accepts a relative path from the
resources/views
directory.
During the view.render call, you can pass the template state/data as 2nd argument.

guides/views/introduction#syntax-guide.title: Syntax Guide
nodes: Before learning about the features of Edge, it is very important to understand the Edge syntax at the fundamental level, since everything else is layers on top of these fundamentals.
There are basically two distinct ways of writing Javascript or logic inside your templates.

guides/views/introduction#the-curly-brac.title: The Curly Braces
nodes: The curly braces (or mustache braces) are commonly used across many different template engines. Edge also uses the same syntax for interpolation.

guides/views/introduction#the-edge-tags.title: The Edge tags
nodes: A fully featured template engine needs many more features than just outputting Javascript expressions. For example: Including partials, writing conditionals and so on. These features are added using the tags API of Edge.
The following is the include tag for including partials.
The following is an each tag for iterating for an array of items. However, the each tag accepts additional markup inside the opening and closing expressions.
Similarly, there are many more tags to enrich the templating experience. The great thing is, Edge also exposes the API for creating your own tags.

guides/views/introduction#comments.title: Comments
nodes: Finally, you can also write comments inside your templates.

Most of the times, you will be generating HTML from your edge templates, so using the standard HTML comments is also fine. However, the Edge comments becomes helpful, when you are using them inside a language that doesn't have comments, like JSON or Markdown.
Output

guides/views/data-flow.title: Data Flow
nodes: You can pass data to the templates at different stages and each stage defines the scope at which the data will be accessible inside the templates. By the end this guide, you will know:
Different API's to pass data to a template
The scope of data at which it is accessible to the templates

guides/views/data-flow#template-state.title: Template State
nodes: The most common way to pass data to a template is during the view.render call. This data object is known as the state of the template.
Rendering View
Template
The state of the template is shared among the partials and the layout, but not with the components, since components have their own state.

guides/views/data-flow#global-state.title: Global State
nodes: Templates also have a global state, which is shared among all the templates and even the components. This is a great place to store the helper methods or some shared configuration.

guides/views/data-flow#defining-globals.title: Defining globals
nodes: The globals must be defined only once. So keeping them inside a provider is a great option. Open providers/AppProvider.ts file and paste the following code snippet inside it.
Now, you can access the timestamp method inside your templates.

guides/views/data-flow#shared-state.title: Shared State
nodes: Finally, the templates can also have shared state. The shared state is similar to globals, but it is specific to a single instance of a view. The shared state is helpful, when you want to have globals, but isolated between HTTP requests.
For example: The request and auth variables added by AdonisJS are part of the shared state.
Sharing data
Rendering View
The above example uses a Route for simpler explaination. However, you can share data from middleware as well and it will be isolated among multiple HTTP requests.

guides/views/data-flow#conclusion.title: Conclusion
nodes: Before passing all the data to a template, Edge will deep merge all these objects in the following order.
Globals
Shared state
Template state

guides/views/interpolation.title: Interpolation
nodes: Interpolation allows you to write Javascript expressions within a markup language like HTML. The output of the Javascript expression is concatenated to the template output value. For example:
Assuming the username variable has value of virk. The output will be as follows:

guides/views/interpolation#javascript-ex.title: Javascript Expressions
nodes: You are not only limited to simple variable references like {{ username }}. Infact, you can write almost any valid JavaScript expression inside the curly braces. Consider the following examples:

guides/views/interpolation#raw-html.title: Raw HTML
nodes: The output of curly braces is escaped to prevent XSS attacks. If you want Edge to not escape the output, then you will have to make use of 3 curly braces {{{, also known as safe mustache.
Also, you can make use of the global safe function to render HTML without escaping it.

guides/views/interpolation#ignoring-inte.title: Ignoring Interpolation
nodes: The syntax for interpolation {{ }} is majorly same across different frameworks and at times it can cause unwanted conflicts. For example:

You want to use Vue.js along with Edge. The interpolation syntax for both is same and hence, Edge will evaluate the expressions before passing them to Vue. However, you can instruct Edge to ignore curly braces by prefixing the @ symbol.

guides/views/conditionals.title: Conditionals
nodes: You can write conditionals inside your templates using the following Edge tags:
@if
@elseif
@else
@unless

guides/views/conditionals#unless.title: Unless
nodes: You can also use the unless tag for writing conditionals. The unless is the opposite of if and at times it feels more natural than writing a negative if.

guides/views/conditionals#ternary-operat.title: Ternary Operator
nodes: You can also write the standard Javascript ternary operator for shorthand if/else statements

guides/views/loops.title: Loops
nodes: Edge offers a uniformed @each tag to iterate over both Arrays and Objects. Consider the following examples:

guides/views/loops#arrays.title: Arrays
nodes: The following example uses @set tag to define an inline Array.
You can also access the iteration index as shown below

guides/views/loops#objects.title: Objects
nodes: Similarly, you can also loop over an object of key-value pair.

guides/views/loops#fallback-message.title: Fallback Message
nodes: The @each tag also let you define a fallback @else statement to show a message when the list is undefined or doesn't have items inside it.

guides/views/layouts.title: Layouts
nodes: The layouts allows you to define the common markup of a web page inside its own file and then other templates can re-use that markup by just replacing the certain sections. In this, you will learn:
How layouts work in Edge
Using sections to inject content inside a layout
Known limitations and using components as an alternative

guides/views/layouts#creating-a-layout.title: Creating a Layout
nodes: Layouts are the standard Edge template files, but written with the purpose to be extended by the other templates. For demonstration, lets create a layout to hold the markup for a blog.
Now, open the newly created file and paste the following contents inside it.
Next, create a new template file that will use the above layout and defines its own content.
Finally, render the posts/index.edge template.
Now, if you visit http://localhost:3333, you must see the content being injected at the right place.

guides/views/layouts#how-it-works.title: How it works?
nodes: The
layout/blog.edge
template is created with a purpose to be used as a layout and hence it defines
@section
that other template can inject content into.
Also, it relies on the
title
variable to set the page title.
The parent template (one using the layout) can inject the content by using the
@section
tag with the same name.
The
@layout
always have to be at the first line in the parent template, otherwise the layout is ignored.

guides/views/layouts#defining-sections.title: Defining sections
nodes: Sections allows you to define areas in your layout that can be overwritten by the parent templates. You can create as many sections as you want, just make sure they all have unique names for a given layout.
Most of the times, the sections inside the layouts are empty. So instead of writing @endsection, you can self close a tag by prefixing it with a bang (!) character.

guides/views/layouts#inheriting-sections.title: Inheriting Sections Content
nodes: The default behavior of sections is to overwrite the contents of a section defined inside a layout. For example:
The master template defines a scripts section that has a list of default scripts.
The parent template re-defines the scripts section with the intention to append a new script.
But, as per the default behavior of sections, the first two scripts defined by the master layout have been removed.
To address this problem, Edge sections comes with an inheritance model. Just like the Javascript classes, you can use the @super tag to inherit the existing content of a section.

guides/views/layouts#limitations.title: Limitations
nodes: The layouts and sections are only evaluated during compile time and this approach comes with its own set of limitations.
The name of the
layout
and the
section
has to be a static string. You cannot compute these names from a Javascript expression evaluated at runtime.
You cannot nest sections inside each other. It is not really a limitation, but instead a design choice.
The parent template can only contain
@section
and
@set
tags. Everything else outside of sections is ignored.

guides/views/partials.title: Partials
nodes: Partials are the re-usable chunks of markup that you can include inside any template. Technically, there isn't anything different about partials, its just a layer for better code organization.
For demonstration, lets create a partial for the website header. Begin by executing the following ace command.
Open the newly created file and paste the following code snippet inside it.
Now, create another template and include the header inside it using the @include tag.
The contents of the header template will be copied to the parent template.

guides/views/partials#dynamic-includes.title: Dynamic Includes
nodes: The @include tag also works with dynamic values evaluated at runtime. For example:

guides/views/partials#conditional-includ.title: Conditional Includes
nodes: Quite often you will find yourself wrapping partials inside conditional statements. For example: Include the partial to show comments, only if post has comments.
Using the includeIf tag, you can shorten the above code snippet to a single line.

guides/views/components.title: Components
nodes: The term Components is widely used in the frontend eco-system, like: the React Components, the Vue Components and so on. The Edge components are not same as the components from the frontend space, its just that Edge borrows some of the concepts from these frameworks.

guides/views/components#what-are-edge-co.title: What are Edge components?
nodes: Edge components are not Web components. There is no concept of Shadow DOM or even Virtual DOM, since the nature of server side templating is completely different from client side templating.
The components in Edge are:
Re-usable markup/template files with their own state.
At the time of rendering, you can pass custom data to the components.
Using slots, you can also inject custom markup to the component structure.

guides/views/components#creating-a-compo.title: Creating a Component
nodes: Let's begin by creating a component for a modal box. We will be using alpinejs for interactivity and bulma css for styling the modal.
The first step is to create a component for the modal. Running the following ace command to create one.
Open the newly created file and paste the following code snippet inside it.

for display the modal actions inside the footer

for showing the button to open the modal box
All HTML classes are part of bulma framework to style the modal box.
The
x-data
@click
handlers are part of AlpineJs. You can replace it with any frontend library of your choice.

Register route

guides/views/components#how-it-works.title: How it works?
nodes: You can render components by using the
@component
tag. It accepts the relative path to the template file, along with optional data object. The data object becomes the state of the component.
The
@slot
tag allows you to define fragments of HTML inside the component body and then the actual component can access them from the
$slots
object.

guides/views/components#slots.title: Slots
nodes: Slots are also part of the component state, but defined in a more succinct manner. If you were to replicate slots manually, this is how you will write them.
Well, writing HTML inside nested objects isn't fun. This is why, Edge comes with a dedicated tag to define slots in a much cleaner and approachable manner.
The username is not accessible by the component, but the slots can access it.

guides/views/components#the-main-slot.title: The main slot
nodes: Every component has a main slot, which doesn't need to be defined explicitly. In the following example, the markup within the opening and the closing statements is part of the main slot.
In other words, every line of code that is not nested inside a named slot is added to the main slot.

guides/views/components#passing-data-to-.title: Passing data to the slots
nodes: The component can pass custom data to the slots at the time of rendering them. For example:
The slot can access the object {foo: 'bar'} as the 2nd argument.

guides/views/in-memory-views.title: In-memory Views
nodes: Edge provides a neat way to register templates directly in-memory without creating files on the disk. This is helpful, when a package author wants to distribute pre-built templates without creating templates in the main application source code.
You can register a template using View.registerTemplate method. For example:
And then use it as a component or as a partial inside your templates.

guides/views/in-memory-views#distributin.title: Distributing Templates Inside a Package
nodes: As a package author you can register custom templates inside a provider boot method.

guides/views/in-memory-views#inside-appl.title: Inside Application Code
nodes: It is recommended to create template files within your views folder. However, if for some reason, you decide to use in-memory templates, you can register them inside the AppProvider within the providers folder or create a preloaded file inside the start folder.

guides/views/in-memory-views#inside-prov.title: Inside Provider
nodes: Open, providers/AppProvider.ts file and paste following code snippet inside it.

guides/views/debugging.title: Debugging
nodes: Since templates are not written in standard programming language, they often lack the context visibility. However, with Edge, we give you enough tooling to inspect and debug templates. By the end of this guide, you will know:
How to inspect
objects
and the
state
of the template.
How to use Chrome DevTools for debugging the template output.

guides/views/debugging#accurate-stack-tr.title: Accurate stack traces
nodes: The first step to better debugging experience is to provide accurate stack traces. Edge does a pretty good job in pointing to the correct filename and the line number of the error.
Following are the screenshots demonstrating compile time and runtime errors.

guides/views/debugging#runtime-errors.title: Runtime errors
nodes: The stack traces works fine with components, partials and layouts too.

guides/views/debugging#inspecting-object.title: Inspecting Objects
nodes: Edge also provides a helper inspect to inspect values within your templates. The helper is similar to JSON.stringify, but also pretty prints the output for better readability.
You can inspect an object as shown below.
You can also inspect the state of a template as shown in the following example.

guides/views/debugging#using-debugger.title: Using Debugger
nodes: Finally, you can also dig into the compiled output by using the @debugger tag. For debugging to work, you will have to use Google Chrome and its DevTools.
For demonstration, lets create a new template and paste following contents inside it.
View

guides/logger.title: Logger
nodes: AdonisJS uses pino logger for logging, since it is one of the fastest logging libraries in Node.js ecosystem and also follows the 12factor app guidelines.

guides/logger#usage.title: Usage
nodes: You need to import the Logger before you can use it.
During an HTTP request, it is recommended to use the logger instance attach to the HTTP Context. The request logger holds a unique request id to keep log messages tighter in scope.
Make sure to enabled request id generation by setting generateRequestId = true inside config/app.ts file.

guides/logger#how-adonisjs-logger-works.title: How AdonisJS Logger works?
nodes: Since, Node.js is a single threaded event-loop, it is very important to keep the main thread free from any extra work required to process or reformat logs.

For this very reason, we opted for pino logger, which does not perform any in-process log formatting and instead encourages you to make use a seperate process for that. In nutshell, this is how the logging works.
You can log at different levels using the Logger API, for example:
Logger.info('some message')
The logs will be send out to
stdout
You can redirect the
stdout
stream to a file or use a seperate process to read and format them.

guides/logger#logging-in-development.title: Logging in Development
nodes: Since logs are always written to stdout, there is nothing special required in the development environment. Also, AdonisJS will automatically pretty print the logs when NODE_ENV=development.

guides/logger#logging-in-production.title: Logging in Production
nodes: In production, you would want to stream your logs to an external service like Datadog or Papertrail. Following are some of the ways to send logs to an external service.
Yes, there is an additional operational overhead of piping the stdout stream to a service. But, the trade off is worth the performance boost you receive. Make sure to check pino benchmarks as well.

guides/logger#using-pino-transports.title: Using Pino Transports
nodes: The simplest way to process the stdout stream is to make use of pino transports. All you need to do is pipe the output to the transport of your choice. For demonstration, let's try to send logs to Datadog.
Install the pino-datadog package from npm package registry.
Start the application in production and pipe the stdout output to pino-datadog.

guides/logger#streaming-to-a-file.title: Streaming to a File
nodes: Another approach is to forward the output of stdout to a physical file on the disk and then configure your logging service to read and rotate the log files.
